item.title: Kit Homes Goolwa – Elevated Flooring Options
item.dc:creator: ITSupport
item.content:encoded:
Can iBuild's kit homes be elevated and what is the building time frame? - Nakita Goolwa, SA

"Can your kit homes be elevated? And what is the building timeframe?

- Nakita,  Goolwa SA

Our kit homes offer flexibility in terms of the foundation, with the option of either an elevated floor system or a slab. For clients who need a quick turnaround, we recommend the elevated floor system as it typically has a shorter construction timeframe. On the other hand, building a slab may take longer due to factors such as waiting for sub-contractors, plumbers, concreters, council inspections, and other variables. In addition, an elevated floor system can be more cost-effective for sites with steep slopes.

The building timeframe for an iBuild home, such as the Avila, typically ranges from 2-3 months. However, the exact timeframe can vary depending on several factors. The size of the kit home is one such factor, as larger homes may take longer to assemble. Weather conditions can also impact the construction process, potentially causing delays. Additionally, the expertise and availability of the carpenters or tradesmen involved in the project can affect the overall building timeframe.

item.title: Kit Homes Victor Harbor – Assembly Advice
item.dc:creator: ITSupport
item.content:encoded:
Do you provide detailed assembly advice? - Nat, Victor Harbor, SA

"Do you supply detailed assembly advice?

- Nat, Victor Harbor, SA

Yes, we offer a comprehensive manual spanning approximately 100 pages, which our customers find to be a valuable resource. Furthermore, we provide a dedicated project manager who will guide you through each step of the process using our project management software, Basecamp. item.title: Kit Homes Moonta Bay – How Much to Customise A Design
item.dc:creator: ITSupport
item.content:encoded:
"How much does it cost to customise a iBuild Kit Home Design?

- Charlie, Moonta Bay SA

The cost of modifying a design can vary based on the extent of changes you desire for one of iBuild's standard designs.

For minor alterations to an iBuild design, you are entitled to two free hours of drafting service covered by the preliminary agreement you sign with iBuild. However, if you require additional changes beyond those two hours, a drafting service fee of $150 + GST per hour will apply (for a minimum of two hours).

To obtain further information about this process, please get in touch with us, and our customer support agents will gladly provide a more detailed explanation.

item.title: Kit Homes Coolamon – Do You Need Council Permission
item.dc:creator: ITSupport
item.content:encoded:
"Do You Need Council Permission? 

- Parag Coolamon, NSW

Generally, you will require council permission, known as planning permission, to build a kit home. However, the specific requirements and processes can differ, so it's important to consult your local council to obtain accurate information about your project site location.

Here are some common types of permissions you may need to obtain from your local council:

The most common type of permission you will need to get for your project is planning permission. This permission relates to land use and ensures that your proposed kit home complies with zoning regulations and local planning schemes. It typically involves submitting a development application with detailed plans, including the kit home's size, design, and location.

You may also need to obtain approvals or permits for connections to essential services such as water, electricity, gas, and sewage. The relevant utility providers or council departments typically grant these permissions.

Before you start your kit home project, make sure to contact your local council. They can guide you through the specific requirements and assist you in navigating the approval process for building your kit home. If you want to take the next step in getting your project rolling, don't hesitate to contact us: click here.

item.title: Kit Homes Jamestown – First Home, Portable Homes
item.dc:creator: ITSupport
item.content:encoded:
Kit Homes Jamestown - First Home Owners Grant and Transportable Homes

"Can you use the first home owner grant for a transportable home?

- Scott Jamestown, SA

It ultimately depends on the regulations and policies set your council and state government. In some cases, the grant may be applicable to transportable or relocatable homes, while in other cases, it may only apply to traditional, fixed-location homes.

To determine if you can use the First Home Owner Grant for a transportable home, you should review the eligibility criteria and guidelines provided by the relevant government agency responsible for administering the grant in your area most likely your local council. They will be able to provide you with accurate and detailed information about the specific requirements and limitations, including any restrictions on the type of homes covered by the grant.

item.title: home ventilation – why is it important?
item.dc:creator: ITSupport
item.content:encoded:
What is Ventilation?

Ventilation is the flow of outdoor air into a building, either controlled by wind (natural ventilation) or with the assistance of ceiling fans and other air-movement controls (mechanical ventilation). Good airflow in a space is important for many factors including maintaining healthy oxygen levels and allowing CO2, odours, and other airborne pollutants to freely leave the space. Airflow is also important to maintaining comfortable temperatures and humidity levels to settle.

Ventilation is so important that it is a requirement of all buildings to have ventilation abilities in every habitable room according to the NCC. Understandably so, as it allows oxygen to enter the room no matter the conditions. Ventilation is typically encouraged through windows and doors, though it also exists in vents, exhaust fans, skylights and fireplaces. Ventilation is also important between rooms. Gaps around doors, vents, windows, plug points, etc. all also contribute to this.

The recent COVID-19 epidemic also reinforced the importance of good ventilation in enclosed spaces. Portable air cleaners and purifiers became almost essential in many indoor working, educational, and recreational environments. this of course was for the clearing of germs in the air, and air clarity became even more important.

What is Airtightness?

Air tightness on the other hand is the intentional blockage of outdoor air into a building. Air-tightness can be important for maintaining comfortable interior living temperatures while also reducing heat loss during winter months or air-conditioned air in cooler months.

All homes need to be designed dynamically to allow states of both airtightness and good ventilation. This is something needed for the variation throughout the year (seasonally) or throughout the day as the outdoor air varies.

item.title: Kit Homes Nelson - Kit Home Design Options
item.dc:creator: ITSupport
item.content:encoded:
"What design options are there?"

- Theo, Nelson VIC

Typically there are three pathways you can take when designing with iBuild. These are:

    1. You love an iBuild design and only want to make some minor tweaks (if any). If you choose this option:

→ You can go straight to the preliminary design agreement. 

→ Make minor changes to the floor plan for free!

    2. Design your own own custom kit home - This includes bringing your own design completely or making significant changes to an iBuild design. 

→ With this option you can get a preliminary agreement with a proposal fee. This fee will form part of the total contract price. 

    3. Bring your own floor plan, elevation, site plan, specs and engineering designs already completed

→ With this option, a custom cost estimate can be given for a proposal fee based on the provided build details

To learn about these options get in contact with us today: click here

item.title: Kit Homes Merriwa- Am I able to use a 1-Bedroom building as a primary residence?
item.dc:creator: ITSupport
item.content:encoded:
"Am I able to use a 1-Bedroom building as a primary residence?"

- Ryan, Merriwa NSW

Yes it can however It is a good idea to contact your local council to
inquire about any applicable restrictions, overlays, and zoning
regulations relevant to your property and area typically, a 1-bedroom
building is considered as a secondary dwelling or ‘granny-flat’ which is
added to a property that already has a primary dwelling. Both dwellings
share the same title, and utilities such as electricity and water
meters are not separate.

In most cases, councils tend to impose restrictions on the maximum
size of a dwelling rather than the minimum size. So, if your building
can be used as a secondary dwelling, it is likely that it can also be
used as a primary dwelling, unless there are specific circumstances such
as a master-planned area with land lease covenants or aesthetic
requirements for heritage sites.

Therefore, if you wish to use the 1-bedroom building as the primary
dwelling on your property, you should inquire directly with your council
for a definitive answer.

If you have any more questions get in touch: click here

item.title: Ventilation Systems & Seasons
item.dc:creator: ITSupport
item.content:encoded:
Passive house design has emerged as a sustainable and energy-efficient approach to creating comfortable living environments. One of the key challenges in passive design is addressing the dynamic nature of seasonal variations. The climate varies all year and so does your need for containing conditioned air in your home (cooled or heated). This article explores how adaptive ventilation strategies play a critical role in ensuring the best indoor air quality and comfort while harnessing natural climate rhythms.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d9btBXMocsc&t=1sSeasonal changes bring shifts in temperature, humidity, and outdoor air quality. Passive houses are designed to minimize the need for mechanical heating and cooling, but effective ventilation remains crucial. Adaptive ventilation strategies leverage these changes to optimize indoor conditions. 

Summer: Embracing Cross-Ventilation and Night Purge

During hot summer months, passive houses can capitalize on cool night air by using cross-ventilation techniques. Designing windows and openings strategically allows for effective airflow, flushing out accumulated heat during the day. Night purging expels warm indoor air, prepping the living spaces for a fresh start each morning.

Autumn: Balancing Heat Recovery and Natural Infiltration

As temperatures drop in autumn, harnessing heat becomes essential. Mechanical ventilation systems with heat recovery, such as energy recovery ventilators (ERVs) and heat recovery ventilators (HRVs), capture warmth from exhaust air and transfer it to incoming fresh air. This maintains a comfortable indoor environment while conserving energy.

Winter: Controlled Ventilation for Heat Retention

Winter demands a delicate balance between ventilation and heat retention. Controlled, intermittent ventilation prevents excessive heat loss while ensuring indoor air remains fresh. Demand-controlled ventilation adjusts airflow based on occupancy, optimizing energy usage and air quality.

Spring: Welcoming Natural Ventilation and Allergen Management

As nature rejuvenates in spring, passive houses can embrace natural ventilation once again. Careful consideration of allergens, such as pollen, is crucial. Filtered ventilation systems, in combination with window design, help manage allergen infiltration while allowing the refreshment of indoor air.

Integration of Smart Technologies: Emerging smart technologies offer opportunities to enhance adaptive ventilation. Sensor-driven systems can monitor indoor air quality, temperature, and occupancy, adjusting ventilation rates accordingly. Automated windows and blinds can work in tandem with these systems to optimize comfort and energy efficiency.

Balancing Energy Efficiency and Comfort: The ultimate goal of adaptive ventilation strategies is to balance energy efficiency and occupant comfort. By aligning ventilation approaches with seasonal variations, passive houses can create spaces that adapt to changing conditions.

Adaptive ventilation strategies are the cornerstone of effective passive house design, allowing residences to breathe with the rhythm of the seasons. By capitalizing on nature's offerings and integrating intelligent technologies, passive houses can achieve optimal indoor air quality, energy efficiency, and comfort throughout the year

item.title: How To Make Your Home Air Tight
item.dc:creator: ITSupport
item.content:encoded:
You can implement several passive home strategies during your homes design and construction to help make your home air tight, such as:

Proper Sealing

Attention to detail during construction is crucial to ensure that all gaps, joints, and penetrations are sealed effectively. This includes using airtight membranes, tapes, and sealants to eliminate potential leakage points. Commonly leakage can occur around doors and windows, including internal and external doors, and skylights. Along with this vents, hatches and heating and cooling systems can also allow conditioned air to escape the home or room. Fireplaces as you can imagine can be quite inefficient due to the required ventilation for the smoke and other gasses to escape. Chimney dampers are another important area to consider air leakage around. It is critical that the installation of these features is done properly to ensure the home is sealed fully.

Quality Windows and Doors

High-performance windows and doors with excellent airtightness properties are installed to minimize air infiltration and heat loss.Of course, this is considering when your windows and doors are closed. When closed we want our windows and doors to block any airflow, opposite to how it acts when opened. we want this dynamic behaviour, where it allows plenty of airflow while open and no airflow when closed. Often the window-to-frame connection is sealed by the manufacturer which is why you want to ensure it is a quality supplier.

Ventilation System

While airtightness is vital, ensuring adequate indoor air quality is equally as important. Passive homes incorporate mechanical ventilation systems with heat recovery, which provide a controlled and efficient exchange of fresh air while recovering heat from outgoing air.

Continuous Insulation

A continuous insulation layer is applied throughout the building envelope, eliminating thermal bridging and maintaining a consistent temperature barrier. Most of these passive design features work in conjunction with each other to allow for optimal functionality and efficiency of your home.

Airtightness

Want to learn more about airtightness and what it means for your home: click here

item.title: Airtightness
item.dc:creator: ITSupport
item.content:encoded:
What is air tightness and air leakage?

Air leakage is the uncontrolled entering or exiting of air into your home through cracks and openings. Air tightness is the ability of the building's envelope to prevent this air leakage. Achieving a high air tightness level is fundamental to minimise the infiltration of the outdoor air and the escape of conditioned indoor air. In this controlled environment, passive homes can considerably reduce energy consumption for heating and cooling purposes, leading to major cost savings and a smaller carbon footprint. Air tightness is critical for a passive home to perform efficiently and provide true environmental benefits.

What about ventilation?

Ventilation is the deliberate movement of air in and out of a home. this is important for air cleanliness, temperature control and reduced risk of mould development. The weather and climate are dynamic throughout the day, month and year, meaning your home should be dynamic also. Balance is required to allow you the choice of air movement or containment.

Air tightness is important to know about before purchasing a house however it is also something you can improve through simple renovations. Bear in mind there are risks of increasing the chance of condensation when airtightness is limited.

Why do we want airtightness?

Airtightness has many benefits

  1. energy efficiency: having a home that is air type races unwanted heat exchange between the inside and outside of your home. Reducing air leakage will lead to a stable indoor temperature reducing the reliance on mechanical heating or cooling systems. This is the key concept in passive homes resulting in substantial energy savings and high efficiency.
  2. In-home comfort: As mentioned above a maintained indoor air temperature and improved air quality contribute to a more comfortable and healthier living environment. Not only this, but airtightness prevents drafts and cold spots while eliminating noise pollution, dust and other pollutants from entering the interior environment.
  3. Moisture control: Air leakage can allow moisture to enter the home, potentially leading to condensation issues with the risk of mould and structural damage over time.
  4. Minimised environmental impacts: As another contributor to a passive design, airtightness can help save energy consumption and GHG emissions due to heating and cooling systems. Passive designs are critical for a sustainable future.

item.title: Kit Homes Charleville - What is Included as part of an iBuild Kit Home?
item.dc:creator: iBuildComms
item.content:encoded:
Kit Homes Charleville - What is Included as part of an iBuild Kit Home?

"What is Included as part of an iBuild Kit Home?" Megan Charleville, QLD

When you choose to build an iBuild kit home there are several standard kit inclusions that can you select for your home. Check out the brief outline of out inclusion list below:

  1. Design - Free Drawings & Free Energy Report for all iBuild Kit Homes
  2. Lock Up Kit - Total of 4 deliveries
    • Frame
    • Insulation (Insulation and Cladding delivered together)
    • Cladding
    • Roofing
    • Windows and Doors
  3. Lining Kit -  Total of 2 Deliveries
    •  Plasterboards & Accessories
    • Second Fix (comes with Robes & Insulation)
    • Robes
    • Insulation
  4. Final Kit - Total of 2 Deliveries
    • Front of Walls Items
    • Kitchen Jointer
    • Note electrical and plumbing items are often not provided due to regulations/ local trade preferences.

Optional Floor Kit - If you chose to do a raised foundation instead of a slab that is something we can help with provide you with. (learn more about raised vs slab foundation click here

  • Bears and Joists
  • Decking
  • Floor Adhesive
  • Yellow Tongue
  • Merbu Hardwood
  • Note Stumps are not included but can be supplied with a footing design

For a more detail about our kit inclusions and exclusions click here

To get started on your iBuild Journey today get in touch with iBuild today by clicking here

item.title: What is Condensation?
item.dc:creator: iBuild
item.content:encoded:
Condensation is a natural outcome when warm, moisture-laden air meets a cooler surface. Although it may seem benign, neglecting condensation can result in home damage and mould growth. This article provides an in-depth exploration of the concept of condensation, its formation, and the possible effects for your residence. It is essential to understand condensation to prevent potentially unhealthy living environments and structural complications in your home.

Condensation defenition

Condensation is the result of a process where water vapour from the air transforms into liquid water against a cooler surface. Like when you take a water jug out of the fridge and leave it on the counter, water droplets from the air condensate on the surface of the bottle. The amount of condensation that takes place is subject to a range of factors, including temperature and humidity.

How Does Condensation Occur?

1. Warm, Moist Air: Warm, moist air is created when you heat your home or when you create moisture through routine activities like cooking, taking a shower, or using humidifiers. Sometimes the weather is also warm and damp which can seep into your home as you use doors and windows.

2. Contact with cooler surfaces: This warm, humid air meets cooler surfaces like windows, walls, mirrors, or cold-water pipes.

3. Dew Point: As the warm air meets these cooler surfaces, it cools down. When it reaches its dew point, the excess moisture condenses on the surfaces, forming water droplets.

Effects of condensation on your home

Condensation leads to water forming on the surface of materials in your home. Many materials such as paints, woods and metals, if not sealed properly, can be damaged due to this water presence.

• Mould growth: black mould can grow when ventilation is poor. This environment is not only unpleasant but also unhealthy. Mould can be joined with a damp smell.

• Rot and Decay: Condensation on wooden surfaces can result in rot and decay, which compromises the structural integrity of your home. This can be troublesome in places like attics, basements, and crawl spaces.

• Peeling Paint and Wallpaper: Paint and wallpaper can peel and bubble because of condensation, resulting in unsightly and expensive damage.

• Corrosion: This can occur on metal surfaces exposed to condensation, such as pipes and appliances. As a result, costly repairs or replacements may be required.

• Reduced Energy Efficiency: Condensation on windows and doors can lessen their insulating capabilities, making it more difficult to keep your home at a comfortable temperature. As you attempt to offset the heat loss, this may result in higher energy costs.

Condensation in certain instances may lead to adverse effects on your window frames, potentially resulting in damage.

Preventing and Managing Condensation

• Proper Ventilation: Ensure your home is well-ventilated to allow excess moisture to escape. Use exhaust fans in bathrooms and kitchens, and open windows when weather permits. As tempting as it is to stay sealed up with the heater on all winter, opening a window and ventilating your home is the easiest way to reduce the risk of condensation.

• Dehumidifiers: The ideal humidity level in your home can be maintained by installing a dehumidifier. This will actually force the moisture in the air to condense in the device itself, meaning the water condensation will not be settling on surface is in your home.

• Insulation: Proper insulation of walls, windows, and doors can help minimize temperature differences between indoor and outdoor surfaces, reducing the likelihood of condensation.

• Double Glazing: Upgrading your windows to double-glazed or insulated windows can significantly decrease condensation on glass surfaces. This ties into the insulation measures mentioned above.

• Weather Stripping: To stop cold air from entering your home, use weather stripping to seal gaps around windows and doors.

• Monitor Humidity Levels: Invest in a hygrometer to monitor indoor humidity levels. Target a relative humidity of between 30 and 50%.

Conclusion

While condensation is indeed a natural process, neglecting it can result in substantial harm to your home. To effectively address and prevent condensation, it is essential to understand its causes and effects. But rest assured it is possible to mitigate condensation, and you can safeguard your home from the impacts and establish a more pleasant and healthy living space.
